SENT.plain: The inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, are chronic relapsing, remitting disorders
Diagnosis, along with assessment of disease activity and prognosis present challenges to managing clinicians
Faecal biomarkers, such as faecal calprotectin, are a non-invasive method which can be used to aid these decisions
Calprotectin is a calcium and zinc binding protein found in the cytosol of human neutrophils and macrophages
It is released extracellularly in times of cell stress or damage and can be detected within faeces and thus can be used as a sensitive marker of intestinal inflammation
Faecal calprotectin has been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of IBD, correlates with mucosal disease activity and can help to predict response to treatment or relapse
With growing evidence supporting its use, over the last decade this faecal biomarker has significantly changed the way IBD is managed
